column4: i have problems deleting a certain directory on my external hdd. the path is something like /media/hdd/folder1/folder2/.../folder7/folder8 - when i'm in folder7 and type "rm folder8", i get "cannot remove `folder8': directory not empty", and when i go into folder8 and type "ls", i get "reading directory .: Input/output error" - is there some way to "force delete" this directory? i understand it may be corrupted or something, is there anything e
lse i can do, save for reformatting the whole hdd?
i had such error on nntpgrab for specific hd, i had to change dir
what do you mean by "change dir"? i've tried renaming the folder in question, and that works, but i still can't delete it
try deleting from nautilus as root
no luck, same thing
what about sending to trash first, then deleting as root
you could try pysdm to auto fstab your partitions

i have no idea what either of those are, but according to a quick google, fstab seems to be related to the partitions table on linux - i don't think that's where the problem is - this is an external hdd (formatted as NTFS), and i can't delete this particular folder at all. i've also tried deleting it from windows, and no luck there either
you cant move the folder to trash neither?
via nautilus you mean? as in, right click->move to trash? nope, that doesn't work
try terminal: sudo nautilus and try to remove file from there
i've already tried that. it doesn't work either
seems like hardass lol
what created this specific folder?
a friend who i lent my hdd to; he copied some files to the hdd in order to move them to another pc; he had no problems copying them, afaik

it may be worth mentioning that this folder where he placed all his files had around 100 thousand files, with very deep directories, with a total of ~5GB of data (ie. a LOT of tiny files), so it's probably windows that caused the corruption when copying them
if you did not tryed pysdm i would reccomend, it auto mounts all your partitions, maybe more luck to remove the file from the new arrangement
i'm not an advanced linux user by any shot, but i know enough that i can assume that your suggestion won't help me here
maybe moving all other files to another hd and reformat?
that's my last-resort-solution - i'd prefer not to do that, if possible
what was that input/output error again?
ls: reading directory .: Input/output error
